22:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-6","children":["Living in ","San Telmo"]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-lg max-w-none text-muted-foreground leading-relaxed","children":[["$","p","0",{"className":"mb-4","children":["San Telmo is Buenos Aires at its most atmospheric. The neighborhood's cobblestone streets, crumbling colonial mansions, and corner tango bars transport you to another era. Every Sunday, the Feria de San Telmo transforms Calle Defensa into a mile-long market of antiques, crafts, and street performers — it's one of the most iconic experiences in the city","."]}],["$","p","1",{"className":"mb-4","children":["Living in San Telmo means immersing yourself in authentic porteño culture. The cafes are old-school (Bar Sur, Café Dorrego), the buildings have character (exposed brick, iron balconies), and the neighbors are a mix of longtime residents, artists, and younger expats drawn by lower rents. The main drawback is safety — while the main streets (Defensa, Estados Unidos, Bolívar) are fine, some side streets can feel sketchy at night, especially south of Avenida Independencia","."]}],["$","p","2",{"className":"mb-4","children":["The neighborhood is gentrifying but still has rough edges. Rents are significantly lower than Palermo or Recoleta, making it popular with artists, writers, and expats on tighter budgets. The Subte C and E lines provide connectivity, and the location near the city center (Microcentro) is actually more convenient than Palermo for some purposes.",""]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"mt-12","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm
